revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Applied ecology''' is a subfield within [[ecology]], which considers the [[applied science|application]] of the science of ecology to real-world (usually management) questions. It is an integrated treatment of the ecological, social, and biotechnological aspects of natural resource conservation and management. It is also called ecological or environmental technology. Applied ecology typically focuses on geomorphology, soils, and plant communities as the underpinnings for vegetation and wildlife (both game and non-game) management.
Aspects of applied ecology include: [[Image:Yosemite Valley with Half Dome in the distance.jpg|300px|thumb|[[Yosemite National Park]] in the [[United States]].]] * [[Agroecology|Agro-ecosystem]] management * [[Biodiversity]] [[conservation biology|conservation]] * [[Biotechnology]] * [[Conservation biology]] * [[Ecosystem restoration]] * [[habitat (ecology)|Habitat]] management * [[Invasive species]] management * [[Protected areas]] management * [[Rangeland]] management * [[Restoration ecology]]
Major journals in the field include:
* ''[[Journal of Applied Ecology]]'' * ''[[Ecological Applications]]'' * [http://www.aloki.hu Applied Ecology and Environmental Research]
Related organizations include: * Ecological Society of America (The Americas) * Society for Ecological Restoration (Global) * [[Institute for Applied Ecology]] (USA) * [[Kazakh Agency of Applied Ecology]] * [[Öko-Institut]] (Institute for Applied Ecology) (in Germany)
==See also== {{Portal|Ecology|Earth sciences|Environment|Biology|Sustainable Development}} *[[Holistic management]] *[[Natural environment]] *[[Natural resource]] *[[Nature]] *[[Environmental impact design]] *[[Landscape planning]]
==References== {{Reflist}}ww.ser.org
www.esa.org{{Br}}
{{Sustainability|state=collapsed}} {{modelling ecosystems|expanded=none}} {{aquatic ecosystem topics|expanded=none}}

Lubchenco,Jane,Entering the Century of the Environment: A New Social Contract for Science,Science 23 Jan 1998: Vol. 279, Issue 5350, pp. 491–497 DOI: 10.1126/science.279.5350.491

Hobbs,Richard J, Hallett,Lauren M, Ehrlich, Paul R, and Mooney,Harold A,Intervention Ecology: Applying Ecological Science in the Twenty-first Century,BioScience (2011) 61 (6): 442-450. doi: 10.1525/bio.2011.61.6.6

[[File:Arasrivermap.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Aras (river)|Aras]] and [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kura river]] map]] [[File:Lagekarte Dschibal.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Arran is located ٍto the west of [[Caspian Sea]]]]
'''Arran''' ([[Middle Persian]] form), also known as '''Aran''', '''Ardhan''' (in [[Parthian language|Parthian]]), '''Al-Ran''' (in [[Arabic]]),<ref name="Minorsky" /><ref name="Bosworth" /> '''[[Aghvank]]''' and '''Alvank''' (in [[Armenian language|Armenian]]), ({{lang-ka|რანი}}-'''Ran-i''' ) or '''[[Caucasian Albania]]'''<ref name="Minorsky" /><ref>{{cite book |title=Genghis Khan: the history of the world conqueror |last=Juvaynī |first=ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn ʻAṭā Malik |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1997 |publisher=Manchester University Press ND |location= |isbn=0-7190-5145-2 |page=148 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NWW7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA148 |accessdate= |quote=''The province of Arran, classical Albania, lay within the great triangle of land formed by the junction of the Kur and the Aras, of which the greater portion now forms part of the Soviet Socialist Republic of Azerbaijan, the remainder belonging to the Republic of Armenia''}}</ref> (in [[Latin]]), was a geographical name used in [[ancient]] and [[medieval]] times to signify the territory which lies within the [[triangle]] of land, lowland in the east and mountainous in the west, formed by the junction of [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kura]] and [[Aras River|Aras]] rivers,<ref name="Bosworth">{{cite encyclopedia |last=Bosworth|first=C. E | title= ARRĀN | encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Iranica | accessdate=2012-07-15|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arran-a-region}}</ref> including the highland and lowland [[Karabakh]],<ref name="Bosworth"/> [[Mil plain]] and parts of the [[Mughan plain]], and in the pre-Islamic times, corresponded roughly to the territory of modern-day [[Republic of Azerbaijan]].<ref name="Bosworth"/> The term is the [[Middle Persian]]<ref name="Journal">''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain and Ireland''. The Society, published 1902, page 64. Text states: ''"In Mustawfi's lists, however, the Arabic article has everywhere disappeared and we have Ray, Mawsil, etc.; while names such as Ar-Ran and Ar-Ras (spelt Al-Ran, Al-Ras in the Arabic writing), which in the older geographers had thus the false appearance of Arab names, in the pages of Mustawfi appear in plain Persian as Arran and Aras."''</ref><ref>Prasad, Ganga. ''The Fountain Head of Religion''. Published by the Book Tree in 2000, page 46</ref> equivalent to the [[Greco-Roman]] ''Albania''. It was known as ''Aghvania'', ''Alvan-k''<ref name="Minorsky">V. Minorsky. Caucasica IV. Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, Vol. 15, No. 3. (1953), p. 504</ref> in [[Armenian language|Armenian]], and ''Al-ran''<ref name="Minorsky"/><ref name="Bosworth"/> (Arabized form of ''Arran''<ref name="Journal"/>) in [[Arabic]].
Today, the term Aran is mainly used in [[Azerbaijan]] to indicate territories consisting of Mil and Mughan plains{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}} (mostly, [[Beylaqan]], [[Imisli|Imishli]], [[Saatli]], [[Sabirabad Rayon|Sabirabad]] provinces of the [[Republic of Azerbaijan]]).{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}} It has also been used by [[Iran]]ian [[historian]] [[Enayatollah Reza]] to refer to the country of Azerbaijan, freeing the name "Azerbaijan" to refer to a region within Iran.<ref>[http://www.iranchamber.com/geography/articles/arran_real_azerbaijan.php "Arran, the real name of Adjerbadjan"], Interview with Reza, Iran Chamber Society, retrieved 2010-02-28.</ref> (The bulk of the territory of Rep. of Azerbaijan was the historic [[Shirvan]] as well as [[Quba Khanate|Kuba]]/Qubbah).
==Etymology== {{see also|List of geographic names of Iranian origin}} According to some legends and ancient sources, such as [[Movses Kagankatvatsi]], (Albanian) ''Arran'' or ''Arhan''<ref>[http://rbedrosian.com/kg7.htm Kirakos' History of the Armenians<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> was the name of the legendary founder of [[Caucasian Albania]], who in some versions was son of [[Noah]]'s son Yafet ([[Japheth]]) and also, possibly the eponym of the ancient Caucasian Albanians (''Aghvan''),<ref>[http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/rus5/Kalank/text11.phtml?id=618 Moses Kalankatuatsi. History of country of Aluank. Chapter IV.]</ref> and/or the Iranian tribe known as [[Alans]] (Alani). The nearby [[Aras river|Araks (Aras) river]] was known to [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] [[geographer]]s as the ''Araxes'', and has a source near from [[Mount Ararat]]. [[James Darmesteter]], in his discussion of the geography of the [[Avesta]]'s ''[[Vendidad]]'' I, observes that the 12th century ''[[Bundahishn]]'' (29:12) identified the "[[Airyanem Vaejah|Airyana Vaego by the Vanguhi Daitya]]" on the northern border of Azerbaijan, and did so "probably in order that it should be as near as possible to the seat of the Zoroastrian religion yet without losing its supernatural character by the counter-evidence of facts."<ref>Darmesteter, James (trans., ed.). "Vendidad." ''Zend Avesta I'' (SBE 4). Oxford University Press, 1880. p. 3, p. 5 n.2,3.</ref> Darmesteter further associated the Vanguhi Daitya river with the Araxes, and compared the name "Airyana Vaego" with that of Arran.<ref>[http://www.avesta.org/vendidad/vd1sbe.htm Darmesteter's translation and notes]</ref>
According to [[C.E. Bosworth]]:
{{cquote|The Georgians knew them [the Caucasian Albanians] as Rani, a form taken over in an Arabized form for the early Islamic geographical term al-Rān (pronounced ar-Rān)''.}}
==Boundaries== {{Main article|History of the name Azerbaijan}}
In pre-Islamic times, Caucasian Albania/Arran was a wider concept than that of post-Islamic Arran. Ancient Arran covered all eastern Transcaucasia, which included most of the territory of modern-day Azerbaijan Republic and part of the territory of [[Dagestan]]. However, in post-Islamic times the geographic notion of Arran reduced to the territory between the rivers of Kura and Araks.<ref name="Bosworth"/>
In a medieval chronicle "''Ajayib-ad-Dunya''", written in the 13th century by an unknown author, Arran is said to have been 30 [[parasang]]s (200 km) in width, and 40 ''farsakhs'' (270 km) in length. All the right bank of the [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kura river]] until it joined with the Aras was attributed to Arran (the left bank of the Kura was known as [[Shirvan]]). The boundaries of Arran have shifted throughout history, sometimes encompassing the entire territory of the present day Republic of Azerbaijan, and at other times only parts of the [[South Caucasus]]. In some instances Arran was a part of Armenia.<ref>Abi Ali Ahmad ibn Umar ibn Rustah, al-A'laq Al-Nafisah, Tab'ah 1,Bayrut : Dar al-Kutub al-ʻIlmiyah, 1998, pg 96-98.</ref>
Medieval [[Islamic]] geographers gave descriptions of Arran in general, and of its towns, which included [[Barda, Azerbaijan|Barda]], [[Beylagan (town)|Beylagan]], and [[Ganja (city)|Ganja]], along with others.
== History of Arran == :''History of Arran is summarized in [[History of Azerbaijan]] section, where you can refer for detailed description.''
===Pre-Islamic=== {{main article|Caucasian Albania}} {{empty section|date=January 2016}}
===Islamic===
Following the [[Islamic conquest of Iran|Arab invasion of Iran]], the Arabs invaded the Caucasus in the 8th century and most of the former territory of [[Caucasian Albania]] was included under the name of Arran. This region was at times part of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] based on [[numismatic]] and historical evidence. Dynasties of [[Parthia]]n or [[Persian people|Persian]] descent, such as the [[Mihranids]] had come to rule the territory during [[Sassanids|Sassanian times]]. Its kings were given title ''Arranshah'', and after the Arab invasions, fought against the caliphate from the late 7th to middle 8th centuries.
Early [[Muslim]] ruling dynasties of the time included [[Rawadids]], [[Sajids]], [[Salarids]], [[Shaddadid]]s, [[Shirvanshahs]], and the [[Shaki Khanate|Sheki]] and [[Tiflis]] emirates. The principal cities of Arran in early medieval times were [[Bardha'a]] (Partav) and [[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Ganja]]. Bardha'a reached prominence in the 10th century, and was used to house a [[mint (coin)|mint]]. Bardha'a was sacked by the [[Rus' (people)|Rus]] and [[Norsemen|Norse]] several times in the 10th century as result of the [[Caspian expeditions of the Rus]]. Bardha'a never recovered after these raids and was replaced as capital by [[Baylaqan]], which in turn was sacked by the Mongols in 1221. After this Ganja rose to prominence and became the central city of the region. The capital of the [[Shaddadid]] dynasty, Ganja was considered the "mother city of Arran" during their reign.
The territory of Arran became a part of the [[Seljuq Empire]], followed by the [[Ildegizid]] state. It was taken briefly by the [[Khwarezmian Empire|Khwarizmid]] dynasty and then overran by [[Mongol Hulagu empire]] in the 13th century. Later, it became a part of [[Chobanid]], [[Jalayirid]], [[Timurid dynasty|Timurid]], and Iranian [[Safavid]], [[Afsharid]], and [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]] states which means at least from 1500 until 1828 when Iran signed the [["Treaty of Turkmenchay"]] after losing a major battle to the expending Russian Empire and as a result had to sign The '''Treaty of Turkmenchay''' ({{lang-ru|Туркманчайский договор}}, {{lang-fa|عهدنامه ترکمنچای}}) in which it had to concede all the [[Caucasus]] territories to Russia.
==People== {{see also|Origin of the Azeris}}
The population of Arran consisted of a great variety of peoples.<ref name="Hewsen">[[Robert H. Hewsen|Hewsen, Robert H]]. ''Ethno-History and the Armenian Influence upon the Caucasian Albanians'', in: Samuelian, Thomas J. (Hg.), Classical Armenian Culture. Influences and Creativity, Chico: 1982, 27-40.</ref> Greek, Roman and Armenian authors provide the names of the some peoples who inhabited the lands between the Kur and Araxes rivers:
* [[Udi people|Utians]] and Mycians — apparently migrants from the south, * [[Caspians]], Gargarians and Gardmans * Sakasenians — of [[Scythians|Scythian]] origin, * Gelians, Sodians, Lupenians, Balasanians — possibly [[Peoples of the Caucasus|Caucasian tribes]], * Parsians and Parrasians — were probably [[Iranian people|Iranian]]
In the late 4th century, when the region passed to Caucasian Albania, its population consisted of Armenians and Armenicized aborigines, though many of the latter were still cited as distinct ethnic entities.<ref name="Hewsen"/>
In pre-Islamic times the population of Arran and most of Caucasian Albania had mostly been Christian who belonged to the [[Church of Caucasian Albania]].<ref name="Bosworth"/> Under Arabic rule (7th to 9th centuries) a part of the population was Islamicized and adopted [[Alevism]]. Muslim chronicles of the 10th century reported that some of the population of Arran spoke al-rānīya, as well as [[Arabic]] and [[Persian language]]s.<ref>[http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/S.Kavkaz/Karaulov/frametext1.htm In Russian, text states: Язык в Адербейджане, Армении и Арране персидский и арабский, исключая области города Дабиля: вокруг него говорят по-армянски: в стране Берда'а язык арранский.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929124502/http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/S.Kavkaz/Karaulov/frametext1.htm |date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="link1">[http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/S.Kavkaz/Karaulov/text7.htm Al-Muqaddasi, 985] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929122446/http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/S.Kavkaz/Karaulov/text7.htm |date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="link2">[http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/S.Kavkaz/Karaulov/text9.htm Ibn-Hawqal, 978] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929121058/http://www.vostlit.info/Texts/Dokumenty/S.Kavkaz/Karaulov/text9.htm |date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref> Because there is no written evidence, some scholars have presumed al-rānīya to be an [[Iranian Languages|Iranian]] dialect<ref>Encyclopedia Iranica, "Azerbaijan: Islamic history to 1941." C. E. Bosworth:"North of the Aras, the distinct, presumably Iranian, speech of Arrān long survived, called by Ebn Hawqal al-rānīya"</ref> while others have presumed it to be a remnant of a Caucasian Albanian language. The area in which there was Ganja, during the 9th to 12th century named Arran; its urban population spoke mainly in Persian.<ref>[http://www.kulichki.com/~gumilev/HE2/he2103.htm История Востока. В 6 т. Т. 2. Восток в средние века.] М., «Восточная литература», 2002. {{ISBN|5-02-017711-3}} (History of the East. In 6 volumes. Volume 2. Moscow, publishing house of the Russian Academy of sciences «East literature»): The multi-ethnic population of Albania's left-bank (of the Kura) at this time is increasingly moving toward the Persian language. Mainly this applies to cities of Aran and [[Shirvan]], as begin from 9-10 centuries named two main areas in the territory of Azerbaijan. With regard to the rural population, it would seem, mostly retained for a long time, their old languages, related to modern Daghestanian family, especially Lezgin. (russian text: Пестрое в этническом плане население левобережной Албании в это время все больше переходит на персидский язык. Главным образом это относится к городам Арана и Ширвана, как стали в IX-Х вв. именоваться два главные области на территории Азербайджана. Что касается сельского населения, то оно, по-видимому, в основном сохраняло еще долгое время свои старые языки, родственные современным дагестанским, прежде всего лезгинскому.</ref><ref>[http://uni-persona.srcc.msu.su/site/authors/djakonov/posl_gl.htm Дьяконов, Игорь Михайлович. Книга воспоминаний. Издательство "Европейский дом", Санкт-Петербург, 1995., 1995]. - {{ISBN|5-85733-042-4}}. cтр. 730-731 [[Igor Diakonov]]. The book of memoirs.</ref>
After the Turkification of the region, the population became Turkic speaking, and thus referred to by [[European ethnic groups|European]]s, particularly the [[Russians]], as Tartars. They were much later called Azerbaijanis.
With the exception of some Uti, the population of Arran which remained Christian, was ultimately absorbed by the Armenians and in part by the Georgians.<ref name="Hewsen"/>
==See also== *[[Caucasian Albania]] *[[Aghuank]] *[[South Caucasus]] *[[Transcaucasia]] *[[Azerbaijan Democratic Republic]] *[[Azerbaijan SSR]] *[[Iranian Azerbaijan]]
==Sources== * Bashi, Munnjim, '''Duwal Al-Islam''' * [[Vladimir Minorsky|Minorsky, V.]],Studies in Caucasian history, Cambridge University Press, 1957 * Volkmar Gantzhorn, '''Oriental Carpets'''

revision.text:
'''Bruce Mortimer Stanley Campbell''', [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]], [[Member of the Royal Irish Academy|MRIA]], [[Member of the Academia Europaea|MAE]], [[Fellow of the Royal Historical Society|FRHistS]], [[Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences|FAcSS]] (born 11 June 1949) is a British [[economic historian]]. From 1995 to 2014, he was Professor of Medieval Economic History at [[Queen's University Belfast]], where he remains an emeritus professor.
== Career == Bruce Mortimer Stanley Campbell was born in [[Hertfordshire]] on 11 June 1949 to Reginald Arthur Mortimer and Mary Campbell. After graduating from the [[University of Liverpool]] in 1970 with a first-class [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in geography, Campbell completed his [[doctorate]] under the supervision of Dr Alan Baker at [[Darwin College, Cambridge]], in 1975, with a thesis entitled "Field systems in eastern Norfolk during the Middle Ages: a study with particular reference to the demographic and agrarian changes of the fourteenth century". He lectured in geography at [[Queen's University Belfast]] from 1973 and the university appointed him to a [[Reader (academic rank)|readership]] in economic history in 1992; he remained in that post until his appointment as Professor of Medieval Economic History in 1995.<ref name="WhWaWh">[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-250242 "Campbell, Prof. Bruce Mortimer Stanley"], ''Who's Who'' (online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2017). Retrieved 3 May 2018.</ref><ref name="prof">[https://pure.qub.ac.uk/portal/en/persons/bruce-campbell(9eb7fb57-b5e7-493a-9dfe-3d62beef83ba).html "Professor Bruce Campbell"], ''Queen's University Belfast''. Retrieved 3 May 2018. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905224356/http://pure.qub.ac.uk/portal/en/persons/bruce-campbell(9eb7fb57-b5e7-493a-9dfe-3d62beef83ba).html |date=5 September 2017}}</ref><ref name="britac">[https://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-bruce-campbell "Professor Bruce Campbell"], ''British Academy''. 3 May 2018. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507084441/https://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-bruce-campbell |date=7 May 2018}}</ref> According to his [[British Academy]] profile, his research relates to "the economic history of late-medieval Britain and Ireland, with particular reference to human-environment interactions during the 14th century and trends in agricultural output and productivity from the 13th to 19th centuries".<ref name="britac"/>
== Honours == Campbell was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Historical Society]] in 2001, an Academician of Social Sciences (later renamed Fellow of the [[Academy of Social Sciences]]) two years later, and a [[Fellow of the British Academy]] (FBA), the United Kingdom's [[national academy]] for the humanities and social sciences, in 2009. He has also been a [[Member of the Royal Irish Academy]] since 1997 and a Member of the [[Academia Europaea]] since 2013.<ref name="WhWaWh"/><ref name="britac"/> He also won the [[Economic History Association]]'s [[Arthur H. Cole Prize]] in 1984, and his book ''English Seigniorial Agriculture 1250–1450'' (2000) was named ''[[List of Latin phrases (P)|proxime accesit]]'' for the [[Royal Historical Society]]'s [[The Whitfield Prize|Whitfield Prize]] in 2000. He was the dedicatee of a [[festschrift]] edited by [[Maryanne Kowaleski]], [[John Langdon (historian)|John Langdon]] and [[Phillipp Schofield]]: ''Peasants and Lords in the Medieval English Economy: Essays in Honour of Bruce M. S. Campbell'' (Brepols, 2015).<ref name="prof"/><ref>Ian Forrest, [https://academic.oup.com/ehr/article-abstract/132/558/1299/4093219 "Review: Peasants and Lords in the Medieval English Economy: Essays in Honour of Bruce M.S. Campbell, ed. Maryanne Kowaleski, John Langdon and Phillipp R. Schofield"], ''[[The English Historical Review]]'', vol. 132, no. 558 (2017), pp. 1299–1301.</ref>
== Selected works == * ''The Great Transition: Climate, Disease and Society in the Late-Medieval World'' (Cambridge University Press, 2016). * (Co-authored with [[Stephen Broadberry|Stephen N. Broadberry]], Alexander Klein, Bas van Leeuwen and [[Mark Overton]]) ''British Economic Growth, 1270–1870'' (Cambridge University Press, 2015). * "Nature as historical protagonist: environment and society in pre-industrial England" (the 2008 [[Tawney Memorial Lecture]]), ''[[Economic History Review]]'', vol. 63, no. 2 (2010), pp. 281''–''314. * ''Field Systems and Farming Systems in Late Medieval England'' (Ashgate, 2008). * ''Land and People in Late Medieval England'' (Ashgate, 2007). * ''The Medieval Antecedents of English Agricultural Progress'' (Ashgate, 2007). * (Co-authored with Ken Bartley) ''England on the Eve of the Black Death: An Atlas of Lay Lordship, Land, and Wealth, 1300–49'' (Manchester University Press, 2006). * ''English Seigniorial Agriculture 1250–1450'' (Cambridge University Press, 2000). * (Edited with [[Richard Britnell|R. H. Britnell]]) ''A Commercialising Economy: England 1086–c. 1300'' (Manchester University Press, 1995). * (Co-authored with James A. Galloway, [[Derek Keene]] and Margaret Murphy) ''A Medieval Capital and its Grain Supply: Agrarian Production and its Distribution in the London Region c. 1300'', Historical Geography Research series, no. 30 (Institute of British Geographers, 1993). * (Edited) ''Before the Black Death: Studies in the "Crisis" of the Early Fourteenth Century'' (Manchester University Press, 1991). * (Co-edited with [[Mark Overton]]) ''Land, Labour and Livestock: Historical Studies in European Agricultural Productivity'' (Manchester University Press, 1991).
Campbell has also produced a database, ''[http://www.cropyields.ac.uk/ Three Centuries of English Crop Yields, 1211–1491]'', bringing together data on pre-modern harvests.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{FBA 2009}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} [[File:Caprivistrip.png|thumb|230px|Map of the Caprivi]] '''Caprivi''', or the '''Caprivi Strip''', is a [[salient (geography)|salient]] of [[Namibia]] which is and has been known by various names.
The salient protrudes eastward for about {{convert|450|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the north-eastern corner of Namibia. It is bordered by [[Botswana]] to the south, and by [[Angola]] and [[Zambia]] to the north. Its eastern tip is only about 1 km from the borders of [[Zimbabwe]]. Within Namibia, it is divided administratively between [[Kavango East]] and [[Zambezi Region|Zambezi]] regions. It is crossed by the [[Okavango River|Okavango]]; the [[Cuando River|Kwando/Chobe river]] forms part of its border with Botswana; and the [[Zambezi]] river forms a part of its border with Zambia. The strip is about {{convert|32|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide, and its area is slightly larger than the US state of [[Maryland]].
Its largest settlement is [[Katima Mulilo]], located at the point where the Zambezi river reaches the Strip.
==Historic and current names==
* The historic name in German is ''Caprivizipfel''. * A less colonial name is '''Okavango Strip'''. * Another former name is '''Itenge'''. This was adopted during a short-lived secession attempt around the year 2000. * This part of the country was anciently known as '''Lyiyeyi (Diyeyi)''', then Caprivi and currently '''Zambezi'''.
==Languages== Inhabitants of the Caprivi Strip speak a number of African languages, mostly members of the [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] language family, with speakers of [[Hukwe language|Hukwe]], a [[Khoisan languages|San]] language, in the northwest of the strip (on the border with Angola. The Bantu languages include [[Yeyi language|Yeyi]] (or 'Yei' or 'Yeeyi'),<ref>Simon S. Donnelly. (1990). ''Phonology and morphology of the noun in Yeeyi.'' University of Cape Town: BA Hons mini-dissertation.</ref> [[Mbukushu language|Mbukushu]], [[Gciriku language|Gciriku]] (or 'Dciriku'), [[Fwe language|Fwe]], [[Totela language|Totela]], and [[Subiya language|Subiya]]. Perhaps a majority in the Caprivi Strip, especially in [[Katima Mulilo]], speaks [[Lozi language|Lozi]]<ref>Derek F. Gowlett. 1989</ref> as a ''[[lingua franca]]''. Many also speak some English and Afrikaans.
==Natural features== [[File:Village in caprivi flood plain.jpg|thumb|250px|Village in the Caprivi Strip]] The area is rich in wildlife and has mineral resources. Of particular interest to the government of Namibia is that it gives access to the [[Zambezi]] River and is thereby a potential trading route to Africa's East Coast. However, the vagaries of the river level, various rapids, the presence of [[Victoria Falls, Zambia|Victoria Falls]] downstream and continued political uncertainty in the region make this use of the Caprivi Strip unlikely, although it may be used for [[ecotourism]] in the future.
Within Namibia the Caprivi Strip provides significant habitat for the critically [[endangered]] Wild African Dog, ''[[Lycaon pictus]]''.<ref>C. Michael Hogan. 2009</ref> It is a corridor for [[African elephant]] moving from Botswana and Namibia into Angola, Zambia and Zimbabwe. National parks found in the Caprivi Strip are [[Bwabwata National Park]], [[Mudumu National Park]] and [[Nkasa Rupara National Park]]. Local communities have organised themselves into communal area conservancies and community forests. People work closely with the Namibian Government to jointly manage natural resources through several programmes set up between the Namibian Government and various donors.<ref name="State of Protected Areas in Namibia">{{cite book|title=State of Protected Areas in Namibia|year=2011|publisher=Ministry of Environment and Tourism|location=Windhoek, Namibia}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Leo von Caprivi.jpg|thumb|right|150|German chancellor [[Leo von Caprivi de Caprera de Montecuccoli]], who gave his name to the Caprivi Strip]]
Caprivi was named after [[Chancellor of Germany (German Reich)|German Chancellor]] [[Leo von Caprivi]] (in office 1890–1894), who negotiated the acquisition of the land in an 1890 exchange with the United Kingdom. Caprivi arranged for the Caprivi strip to be annexed to [[German South West Africa]] in order to give Germany access to the [[Zambezi|Zambezi River]] and a route to Africa's east coast, where the colony of [[German East Africa]] (now part of [[Tanzania]]) was situated. The river later proved unnavigable and inaccessible to the [[Indian Ocean]] due to the [[Victoria Falls, Zambia|Victoria Falls]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/05/a-few-salient-points/?_r=0|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017020632/http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/05/a-few-salient-points/?_r=0|dead-url=yes|archive-date=17 October 2013|title=A Few Salient Points|first=|date=5 December 2011|website=|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=|author=Frank Jacobs}}</ref> The transfer of territory was a part of the [[Heligoland-Zanzibar Treaty]] of 1890, in which Germany gave up its interest in [[Zanzibar]] in return for the Caprivi Strip and the island of [[Heligoland]] in the [[North Sea]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Perras, Arne |title=Carl Peters and German Imperialism 1856-1918 : A Political Biography: A Political Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B02hIAIrsEgC&pg=PA168|year=2004|publisher=Clarendon Press|pages=168–79}}</ref>
In 1976, the South African administration established the pseudo-independent [[East Caprivi|Eastern Caprivi homeland]] with its own flag, national anthem, and coat of arms.<ref name="growth">{{cite news|title=Rapid growth to urban centre|last=Inambao|first=Chrispin|date=<!-- Katima Mulilo 75th anniversary supplement to New Era, --> December 2010|newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]]}}</ref> It remained under direct ''de facto'' control of the South African government in Pretoria until 1980, when its administration was transferred to [[South West Africa|South Africa's administration]] in Windhoek.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lenggenhager|first=Luregn|title=Nature, War and Development: South Africa's Caprivi Strip, 1960–1980|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/03057070.2015.1025337|journal=Journal of Southern African Studies|language=en|volume=41|issue=3|pages=467–483|doi=10.1080/03057070.2015.1025337}}</ref>
In the late 20th century, the Caprivi Strip attracted attention when Namibia and Botswana took a long-standing dispute over its southern boundary to the [[International Court of Justice]]. The core of the [[Kasikili#Territorial dispute|territorial dispute]] concerned which channel of the [[Chobe River]] was the [[thalweg]], the ''bona fide'' international boundary. This was important, as, depending on the decision, a large island (known as [[Kasikili]] or Seddudu, by Namibia and Botswana respectively) would fall into one or the other's national territory. The Botswana government considered the island as an integral part of the [[Chobe National Park]], whereas the Namibian government, and many inhabitants of the eastern Caprivi Strip, held that not only was the island part of the original German–British agreement, but generations of inhabitants had used it for seasonal grazing, for reed-gathering, and as a burial site. In December 1999, the International Court of Justice ruled that the main channel, and hence the international boundary, lay to the north of the island, thus making the island part of Botswana.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070309223831/http://www.icj-cij.org/icjwww/idocket/ibona/ibonaframe.htm The Court finds that Kasikili/Sedudu Island forms part of the territory of Botswana] (archive link)</ref>
==Politics== The Caprivi Strip is of politico-strategic military importance. During the [[Rhodesian Bush War]] (1965–1979), [[African National Congress]] operations against the [[South Africa]]n government (1965–1994) and the [[Angolan Civil War]] (1975–2002), the Strip saw continual military action and multiple incursions by various armed forces using the Strip as a corridor to access other territories.{{fact|date=November 2018}}
===Caprivi conflict=== {{main|Caprivi conflict}}
The [[Caprivi conflict]] involved an armed conflict in [[Namibia]] between the [[Caprivi Liberation Army]] (CLA), a [[Rebellion|rebel]] group aiming for the secession of the Caprivi Strip led by [[Mishake Muyongo]], and the Namibian government. Its main eruption occurred on 2 August 1999 when the CLA launched an attack in Katima Mulilo, occupying the state-run radio station and attacking a police station, the Wanella border post, and an army base. Namibian armed forces quashed the attempt at [[secession]] within a few days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://namibweb.com/article2.htm|title=Civil supremacy of the military in Namibia: A retrospective case study|publisher=NamibWeb|accessdate=2008-11-08}}</ref>
==References== *Derek F. Gowlett. 1989. The parentage and development of Lozi. ''Journal of African Languages and Literature'', 11, 127–149. *C. Michael Hogan. 2009. [https://web.archive.org/web/20101209234758/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=35993 ''Painted Hunting Dog: Lycaon pictus'', GlobalTwitcher.com, ed. N. Stromberg]
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{Orphan|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Dan Blumberg | image = Prof. Dan Blumberg.jpg | image_size = 220px | field = [[Geography]] | workplaces = [[Ben-Gurion University of the Negev]] | doctoral_advisors = [[Ronald Greeley]] and [[Anthony Brazel]] | website = {{URL| http://in.bgu.ac.il/en/epif/Pages/Prof--Dan-Blumberg.aspx/ }} }}
'''Dan G. Blumberg''' is a professor in the Department of Geography and Environmental Development at [[Ben-Gurion University of the Negev]] and currently serves as Vice-President and Dean for Research and Development and Director of the Homeland Security Institute. He is also director of the Earth and Planetary Image Facility, a remote sensing research laboratory.<ref>[http://in.bgu.ac.il/en/epif/Pages/Homepage1.aspx Earth and Planetary Image Facility ]</ref><ref>[http://web.bgu.ac.il/Eng/humsos/departments/geog/AcademicStaff/danny.htm Staff Members]</ref>
==Education== Blumberg earned a Ph.D. from [[Arizona State University]] (1993) where he studied and worked in the Planetary Geology Group, a NASA sponsored research group, where he focused on studying aeolian processes (wind-blown sand transport and deposition) on Earth, Mars, and Venus comparatively and the use of microwave radar remote sensing to image terrestrial surfaces. The title of His Ph.D. thesis was "Prediction of Aeolian Processes using Radar Remote Sensing and Numerical Models". In his thesis he used AIRSAR data in preparation for NASA's upcoming Spaceborne Radar Laboratory Missions (SRL-1 and 2) to study geological morphologies. Blumberg's Ph.D. Advisors were [[Ronald Greeley]] and Anthony Brazel and on his committee served Phil Christensen and Mel Marcus. Blumberg continued to do a postdoctoral term in the group working on the shuttle radar missions and became an Associate Research Faculty member at Arizona State University in the Geological Sciences department.
==Career== Blumberg joined BGU in 1996 as a lecturer in the Department of Geography and Environmental Development. He developed the field of remote sensing within the Department of Geography and Environmental Development and has been a key player together with scientists from the Faculty of Engineering and The Blaustein Institutes for Desert Research in turning BGU into a world-renowned research institute in the field.
He has gone on to be one of the leading scientists in Aeolian research with a strong focus on the use of remote sensing to map windblown and windswept terrains.
In 2004 Blumberg was promoted to Associate Professor. Between 2006 and 2010 he served as Chair of the Department of Geography and Environmental Development before being appointed to Deputy VP and Dean for R&D. In 2008 Blumberg was promoted to the level of full Professor. In 2014 Blumberg Vice President for Research of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev. Since 2016, Prof. Blumberg is taking part on the advisory board of [[Utilis]], a satellite-based leak detection company
==Research and students== Blumberg has published numerous scientific papers and has supervised more than 30 Ph.D. and masters students. His research spans a wide arena of remote sensing applications. His primary scientific research interest has been in [[Planetary geology]] with a focus on aeolian bedforms and the use of remote sensing to study arid zone environments but in the process has also impacted upon other applications such homeland security,<ref>[http://www.bgu.ac.il/hsi Homeland Security Institute]</ref> rapid response,<ref>[http://in.bgu.ac.il/en/PREPARED/Pages/default.aspx PREPARED center for Emergency Response Research]</ref> target and anomaly detection and situational awareness. Within these studies Blumberg has been developing novel methods to analyze multi dimensional image cubes including polarimetric synthetic aperture radar and hyperspectral data. Blumberg was a Co-Investigator on the SRL (SIR-C mission) through Prof. Ronald Greeley of Arizona State University who was a PI on the mission. Blumberg has served as a P.I. on many research projects for the Israel Space Agency ,on the TerraSar-x mission of the German Space Agency and more. In his research he has combined field studies with the use of space and airborne images. Blumberg has always promoted the philosophy that understanding satellite images requires scientists to have a strong field background. In his own research he has conducted field work in the North American Deserts, the Central Asian Deserts and in the Middle East. Blumberg has also promoted the involvement of students in community outreach as a way to spread scientific knowledge gathered within academia and increase equal opportunity to reach academic education.
==External links== *[http://profiler.bgu.ac.il/frontoffice/ShowUser.aspx?id=1110 Dan Blumberg's profile] *[http://in.bgu.ac.il/en/epif/Pages/Homepage1.aspx The Earth and Planetary Image Facility]

page.title: First-level NUTS of the European Union

revision.text:
{{redirect|NUTS 1|the satellite|NUTS 1 (satellite)}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{No footnotes|date=July 2016}} The [[Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics|Classification of Territorial Units for Statistics]], (NUTS, for the French ''{{lang|fr|nomenclature d'unités territoriales statistiques}}''), is a [[geocode]] [[standardization|standard]] for referencing the administrative divisions of countries for statistical purposes. The standard was developed by the [[European Union]]. There are three levels of NUTS defined, with two levels of [[local administrative unit]]s (LAUs) below. Depending on their size, not all countries have every level of division. One of the most extreme cases is Luxembourg, which has only LAUs; the three NUTS divisions each correspond to the entire country itself. Below are the ''first level NUTS regions'' of the European Union. {| border="0" class="toccolours" |- ! {{MediaWiki:Toc}} |- | align="center" | [[#Austria|Austria]] — [[#Belgium|Belgium]] — [[#Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] — [[#Cyprus|Cyprus]] — [[#Czech Republic|Czech Republic]] — [[#Germany|Germany]] — [[#Denmark|Denmark]] — [[#Estonia|Estonia]]
[[#Spain|Spain]] — [[#Finland|Finland]] — [[#France|France]] — [[#Greece|Greece]] — [[#Croatia|Croatia]] — [[#Hungary|Hungary]] — [[#Ireland|Ireland]] — [[#Italy|Italy]] — [[#Lithuania|Lithuania]] — [[#Luxembourg|Luxembourg]] — [[#Latvia|Latvia]]
[[#Malta|Malta]] — [[#Netherlands|Netherlands]] — [[#Poland|Poland]] — [[#Portugal|Portugal]] — [[#Romania|Romania]] — [[#Sweden|Sweden]] — [[#Slovenia|Slovenia]] — [[#Slovakia|Slovakia]] — [[#UK|United Kingdom]] __NOTOC__
[[#See also|See also]] — [[#References|References]] |}

revision.text:
The '''Flags of the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Socialist Republic]]s''' were all [[defacement (flag)|defaced]] versions of the [[flag of the Soviet Union]], which featured a golden [[hammer and sickle]], (the only exception being the Georgian SSR, which used a red hammer and sickle), and a gold-bordered [[red star]] on a red field. ==History== When [[Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic|Byelorussia]] and [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]] were the founding members of the [[United Nations]] in 1945, all of their flags were red with only small markings in upper left corners and needed distinct flags for each other. In February 1947, with UN pressure, the [[Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union]] adopted a resolution, which each of its republics were recommended to develop and adopt new national flags. So they expressed the idea of a union state, asked to use the symbols of the State flag of the Soviet Union, such as the gold [[hammer and sickle]] and the [[red star]], as well as maintain the predominance of red color on the flag of the Union republics. National, historical and cultural features of each republic was instructed to express the other colors and the order of their location, as well as the location based on the national ornament. After the competitions for the best projects in the 1949–1954 years of the new flags of the 16 republics were developed and adopted. The authorities in Ukraine and Byelorussia were the first to adopt the flags on July 5, 1950, and December 25, 1951, respectively. All others followed suit between 1952 and 1953 with the last republic, the Russian SFSR, adopted the flag on January 9, 1954.[http://www.vexillographia.ru/russia/index.htm Государственные флаги РСФСР] Following the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] on December 26, 1991, only [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Turkmenistan]] and [[Ukraine]] retained their Soviet republic flags as independent states until the new official flags were adopted in 1992. Their final versions prior to re-adoption of the non-Soviet national flags were as follows: {| style="width:100%; background-color:#fff; border: 1px #6082B6 solid; line-height:130%;" |- ! style="width:10 %;background-color:#a9a9a9; color:#fff; text-align:left;"| Republic !! style="width:15 %; background-color:#a9a9a9; color:#fff; text-align:left;"| Flag !! style="width:15 %;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Date adopted !! style="width:30 %; background-color:#a9a9a9; color:#fff; text-align:left;"| Description !! style="width:10 %;background-color:#a9a9a9;color:#fff;text-align:left;"| Present day flag |- |
'''[[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Russian SFSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| January 7, 1954 || [[Flag of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
The state flag of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic presents itself as a red rectangular sheet with a light-blue stripe at the pole extending all the width which constitutes one eighth length of the flag. ||
[[File:Flag of Russia.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Russia]]
|- |
'''[[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Ukrainian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| July 5, 1950 || [[Flag of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A horizontal bicolor of red over azure (light blue) with the golden hammer and sickle and gold-bordered star on top of the canton. ||
[[File:Flag of Ukraine.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Ukraine]]
|- |
'''[[Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic|Byelorussia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Byelorussian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| December 25, 1951 || [[Flag of the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A horizontal bicolor of red over green in a 2:1 ratio and the golden hammer and sickle with the bordered star on the canton, with a white ornamental pattern on a red vertical stripe at the hoist. ||
[[File:Flag of Belarus.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Belarus]]
|- |
'''[[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|Uzbekistan]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of the Uzbek SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| August 25, 1952 || [[Flag of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A triband flag with the colors (from top to bottom) red, blue, and red, with the blue band frimbrated in white, with a golden hammer and sickle in the upper canton. ||
[[File:Flag of Uzbekistan.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Uzbekistan]]
|- |
'''[[Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic|Kazakhstan]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Kazakh SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| January 24, 1953 || [[Flag of the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A red flag with blue stripe and a golden hammer and sickle and a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton. ||
[[File:Flag of Kazakhstan.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Kazakhstan]]
|- |
'''[[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Georgia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Georgian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| April 11, 1951 || [[Flag of the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with the red hammer and sickle with a red star in a blue sun in canton, blue bar in upper part of flag. ||
[[File:Flag of Georgia (country).svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Georgia (country)|Flag of Georgia]]
|- |
'''[[Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic|Azerbaijan]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Azerbaijan SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| October 7, 1952 || [[Flag of the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with a golden hammer and sickle and a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton and an horizontal blue band on the bottom fourth. ||
[[File:Flag of Azerbaijan.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Azerbaijan]]
|- |
'''[[Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic|Lithuania]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Lithuanian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| July 15, 1953 || [[Flag of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A red flag with the golden hammer and sickle and a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton with the white thin stripe and green thick band on the bottom. ||
[[File:Flag of Lithuania.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Lithuania]]
|- |
'''[[Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldavia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Moldavian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| January 31, 1952 || [[Flag of the Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with the green horizontal stripe and the golden hammer and sickle with a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton. ||
[[File:Flag of Moldova.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Moldova]]
|- |
'''[[Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic|Latvia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Latvian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| January 17, 1953 || [[Flag of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with a golden hammer and sickle and a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton with the blue and white rippling water at the bottom. ||
[[File:Flag of Latvia.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Latvia]]
|- |
'''[[Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic|Kirghizia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Kyrgyz SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| December 22, 1952 || [[Flag of the Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A red field with a golden hammer and sickle and a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton with two navy blue bars and a white stripe in the middle of the flag. ||
[[File:Flag of Kyrgyzstan.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Kyrgyzstan]]
|- |
'''[[Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic|Tajikistan]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Tajik SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| March 20, 1953 || [[Flag of the Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A triband flag sporting the Pan-Iranian colors of red, white and green, manifested in the large white and green stripes in the middle of the red flag, with a golden hammer and sickle in the upper canton. ||
[[File:Flag of Tajikistan.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Tajikistan]]
|- |
'''[[Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic|Armenia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Armenian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| December 17, 1952 || [[Flag of the Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with the blue horizontal stripe and the golden hammer and sickle with a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton. ||
[[File:Flag of Armenia.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Armenia]]
|- |
'''[[Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkmenia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Turkmen SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| August 1, 1953 || [[Flag of the Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with a golden hammer and sickle and a gold-bordered red star in its upper canton with two blue bars in the middle of the flag. ||
[[File:Flag of Turkmenistan.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Turkmenistan]]
|- |
'''[[Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic|Estonia]]'''
||
[[File:Flag of Estonian SSR.svg|200px|border]]
|| February 6, 1953 || [[Flag of the Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A red flag with the golden hammer and sickle and outlined star above a band of blue water waves near the bottom. ||
[[File:Flag of Estonia.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of Estonia]]
|- |
'''[[Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic|Karelia]]'''The [[Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic|Karelo-Finnish SSR]] was a short-lived Union Republic formed in 1940 from the [[Karelian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Karelian ASSR]] with territory ceded from Finland in the [[Winter War]]. In 1956, it was demoted back to an ASSR within the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|RSFSR]].
||
[[File:Flag of the Karelo-Finnish SSR.svg|200px|border]]
||March 3, 1953 || [[Flag of the Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic|(Main article)]]
A plain red flag with the golden hammer and sickle with a red star with the blue and green stripes on the bottom. ||
[[File:Flag of Karelia.svg|100px|border]]
[[Flag of the Republic of Karelia|Flag of Karelia]]
(federal subject of Russia)
|} ==Flags of other republics== Other [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Union Republics]] and [[autonomous republics of the Soviet Union|autonomous republics]] existed within the Soviet Union, mostly using flags on a similar pattern, or the flag of their "parent" Union Republic, further defaced. Today, the only former Soviet Union territories that use modified versions of their original Soviet flag are the republic of [[Transnistria]] (a [[list of states with limited recognition|state of limited recognition]], formerly part of the [[Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldavian SSR]]) and [[Flag of Belarus|Belarus]] (since 1995). The official flags of the ASSRs were seldom used, and were generally the flag of the republic to which the ASSR belonged, defaced with the ASSR name in its own language(s) and the official language of the SSR; flags matching this pattern are not displayed in the gallery below: File:Flag of Abkhazian SSR.svg | [[Flag of the Abkhazian Soviet Socialist Republic|Flag]] of the [[Socialist Soviet Republic of Abkhazia|SSR of Abkhazia]] {{nowrap|(1921–31)}}Despite its name, the [[Socialist Soviet Republic of Abkhazia|SSR of Abkhazia]] was never a [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Union Republic of the Soviet Union]] but had a special status as a ''contractual republic'' of the [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Georgian SSR]], more similar to the administrative republics of the Soviet Union; see [[Socialist Soviet Republic of Abkhazia#Status|Socialist Soviet Republic of Abkhazia: Status]]. File:Flag of the Bukharan People's Soviet Republic.svg | Flag of the [[Bukharan People's Soviet Republic|Bukharan PSR]] {{nowrap|(1920–25)}}The [[Bukharan People's Soviet Republic]] was a short-lived [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] state that governed the former [[Emirate of Bukhara]] during the years immediately following the [[October Revolution|Russian Revolution]]. In 1924, its name was changed to the Bukharan SSR. After the [[national delimitation in the Soviet Union#National delimitation in Central Asia|redrawing of borders by nationality]] in [[Soviet Central Asia]], its territory was assigned mostly to the [[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|Uzbek SSR]] and some to the [[Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkmen SSR]]. File:Flag of Khiva 1920-1923.svg | Flag of the [[Khorezm People's Soviet Republic|Khorezm PSR]] {{nowrap|(1920–25)}}The [[Khorezm People's Soviet Republic]] was created as the successor to the [[Khanate of Khiva]] in 1920, when the khan abdicated in response to popular pressure. In 1923, it was transformed into the Khorezm SSR. A year later, it was divided between the [[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|Uzbek]] and [[Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkmen]] SSRs and the [[Karakalpak Autonomous Oblast|Karakalpak AO]] during the [[national delimitation in the Soviet Union#National delimitation in Central Asia|national delimitation]] in [[Soviet Central Asia]]. File:Flag of Mountain ASSR (1921-1924).svg | Flag of the [[Mountain Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Mountain ASSR]] {{nowrap|(1921–24)}}After the [[October Revolution|Russian Revolution]], the [[Mountainous Republic of the Northern Caucasus]] was established; once Soviet rule was established during the [[Russian Civil War]], the republic was converted to an [[autonomous republics of the Soviet Union|ASSR]] of the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|RSFSR]]. Over the course of its three-year existence, the Mountain ASSR was partitioned into various autonomous [[okrug]]s and [[oblast]]s. File:Flag of Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic (1925-1932).svg | [[Flag of the Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Flag]] of the [[Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldavian ASSR]] {{nowrap|(1925–40)}}The [[Moldavian Autonomous Oblast|Moldavian AO]], within the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukrainian SSR]], was upgraded to become the [[Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldavian ASSR]], encompassing modern [[Transnistria]] (generally recognised as being within [[Moldova]]) and a number of territories that are now part of [[Ukraine]], with the intention of winning over [[Bessarabia]]ns and the first step towards a revolution in [[Greater Romania|Romania]]. In 1940, as a result of the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]], Bessarabia and Northern [[Bukovina]] were ceded to and [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina|occupied]] by the Soviet Union during [[World War II]]; the ASSR and the newly-won territories were upgraded to a Union Republic as the [[Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldavian SSR]]. File:Flag of the Tajik ASSR (1929.02-1929.04).svg | Flag of the [[Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Tajik ASSR]] {{nowrap|(1924–29)}}The [[Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Tajik ASSR]] was an autonomous republic within the [[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|Uzbek SSR]], created in 1924 during the [[national delimitation in the Soviet Union#National delimitation in Central Asia|redrawing of borders by nationality]] in [[Soviet Central Asia]]. Five years later it was promoted to a full Union Republic as the [[Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic|Tajik SSR]]. File:Flag of Transcaucasian SFSR.svg | [[Flag of the Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic|Flag]] of the [[Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic|Transcaucasian SFSR]] {{nowrap|(1922–36)}}In 1922, the [[Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic|Armenian]], [[Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic|Azerbaijan]] and [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Georgian]] SSRs were merged to form the [[Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic|Transcaucasian SFSR]]. In 1936, they were repartitioned back into the original three Union Republics. File:Flag of Transnistria (state).svg | '''[[Flag of Transnistria|Flag]] of [[Transnistria]]''' {{nowrap|(1990/92– )}}'''Current flag.''' The flag of [[Transnistria]], a [[list of states with limited recognition|state of limited recognition]], is near-identical to the flag of the former Moldavian SSR. When Moldova became independent, some places in Transnistria refused to fly the new [[Flag of Moldova|Moldovan flag]] and continued to fly the flags of the Soviet Union and of the Moldavian SSR. The SSR flag was officially reintroduced as the flag of Transnistria in 2000. Despite the flag and coat of arms, Transnistria is not a [[communist state]]. File:Flag of Turkestan ASSR (1919-1921).svg | Flag of [[Turkestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkestan ASSR]] {{nowrap|(1918–24)}}The [[Turkestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkestan ASSR]] (initially, the Turkestan Socialist Federative Republic) was an autonomous republic of the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|RSFSR]] located in [[Soviet Central Asia]]. Upon dissolution, the Turkestan ASSR was split into the [[Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic|Turkmen SSR]], the [[Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic|Uzbek SSR]], the [[Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Tajik ASSR]], the [[Kara-Kirghiz Autonomous Oblast|Kara-Kirghiz AO]] and the [[Karakalpak Autonomous Oblast|Karakalpak AO]]. ==See also== *[[Coats of arms of the Soviet Republics]] *[[Flags of the federal subjects of Russia]] ===Notes=== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons}} *[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/su_tab.html FotW chart of all the flags of the SSRs through history] {{Soviet Union topics}} {{USSR flags}} {{Lists of flags}} [[Category:Lists and galleries of flags|Soviet Republics]] [[Category:Flags of the Soviet Union| ]] [[Category:Soviet Union-related lists|Flags]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox fictional location | name = Green Hill Zone | colour = | image = [[File:SonicTheHedgehog1.png|250px]] | imagesize = | caption = Green Hill Zone as it appears in the original ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (1991 video game)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' | source = ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' | creator = [[Hirokazu Yasuhara]]<ref name="Yasuhara">{{cite journal|author=Staff|title=Sonic's Architect: GI Interviews Hirokazu Yasuhara|journal=[[Game Informer]]|issue=124|volume=13|date=August 2003|pages=114–116}}</ref> | genre = [[Platform game|Platforming]] | people = [[Sonic the Hedgehog (character)|Sonic the Hedgehog]], [[Doctor Eggman]] | first = ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (1991 video game)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' (1991) }} {{nihongo|'''Green Hill Zone'''|グリーンヒルゾーン|Gurīn Hiru Zōn|lead=yes}} is the first [[level (video gaming)|level]] of the 1991 [[Sega Genesis]] video game ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (1991 video game)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]''. The level is grassy and lush, with environmental features such as palm trees, [[vertical loop]]s and cliffs, and is the home of numerous forest animals. Like the game's other levels, Green Hill comprises three acts; in the third, Sonic fights antagonist [[Doctor Eggman]] before moving to the second level, Marble Zone. It was constructed by [[level design]]er [[Hirokazu Yasuhara]] and its musical theme was created by [[Masato Nakamura]].
Green Hill Zone is considered to be a classic within both the ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' series and in video games in general. The level and its music have also received positive opinions from critics. It has appeared in other games, such as ''[[Sonic Adventure 2]]'', ''[[Sonic Generations]]'', ''[[Sonic Mania]]'', and ''[[Sonic Forces]]''. Critics have noted a Green Hill-like aesthetic in levels of other games.
==History== Green Hill is the first level of ''Sonic the Hedgehog''. Located on South Island,<ref name="Sonic manual">{{cite book | type=manual booklet | title=Sonic the Hedgehog | date=1991 | language=Japanese}}</ref>{{rp|4}} it is a lush, grassy stage with unique features like droopy palm trees<ref name="cubicle"/> and crumbling cliffs.<ref name="Sonic manual"/>{{rp|7}} In addition, as with later levels in the game, Green Hill has environmental features and obstacles like ramps,<ref name="cubicle"/> [[vertical loop]]s, tunnels, spring-boards, spikes,<ref name="Sonic manual"/>{{rp|7}} and [[Saved_game#Checkpoints|checkpoints]].<ref name="Sonic manual"/>{{rp|5}} It is normally populated by woodland creatures, but antagonist [[Doctor Eggman]] imprisons them inside robots known as Badniks prior to the events of the game, so the player must destroy them to free the animals.<ref name="Sonic manual"/>{{rp|2}} Green Hill consists of three acts, and the end of Act 3 features a [[boss (video gaming)|boss]] battle with Eggman.<ref name="Sonic manual"/>{{rp|10}} After beating Eggman, Sonic moves on to the second level, the lava-themed [[Marble Zone]].<ref name="Sonic manual"/>{{rp|7}}
''Sonic the Hedgehog'' was created by the newly formed [[Sonic Team]], a 15-member [[Sega]] subsidiary formed to create a character that could compete with [[Nintendo]]'s [[Mario]]. The game's [[level design]] was handled by [[Hirokazu Yasuhara]],<ref name=1up>{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/features/essential-50-sonic|title=Sonic Boom|website=[[1UP.com]]|last=Kennedy|first=Sam|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> and the musical theme was composed by [[Masato Nakamura]] from the Japanese band [[Dreams Come True (band)|Dreams Come True]].<ref name=cvg/> In designing Green Hill, Yasuhara was inspired by the U.S. state of [[California]], while the game's color scheme in general was influenced by the work of [[pop art]]ist Eizin Suzuki.<ref name=retro>{{cite journal|journal=[[Retro Gamer]]|issue=100|date=February 2012|title=The Making of Sonic the Hedgehog|pages=46–49}}</ref> While the original game was a [[2D computer graphics|2D]] [[side-scroller]], Green Hill was remade in full [[3D computer graphics|3D]] as a secret level in the 2001 game ''[[Sonic Adventure 2]]''; the player unlocks it after collecting all 180 of the emblems found by completing the game's many objectives.<ref>{{cite video game|title=[[Sonic Adventure 2]]|publisher=[[Sega]]|developer=[[Sega Studio USA]]|date=June 19, 2001|quote='''Caption:''' Extra Stage: Green Hill|level=Green Hill}}</ref> The 2011 game ''[[Sonic Generations]]'', a title that revisits past entries in the [[Sonic the Hedgehog|''Sonic'' series]], features both 2D ("Classic") and 3D ("Modern") versions of Green Hill, as well as of numerous other ''Sonic'' levels.<ref name=gens>{{cite web |url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-sonic-generations-214666.phtml|website=Destructoid |last=Sterling|first=Jim|title=Review: Sonic Generations|date=October 31, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> A reinterpretation of the level appears in the 2017 title ''[[Sonic Mania]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Paget|first=Mat|title=Two New Sonic Games Announced, Seek to Recapture the Glory Days|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/two-new-sonic-games-announced-seek-to-recapture-th/1100-6442097/|accessdate=July 23, 2016|date=July 23, 2016}}</ref> Green Hill Zone reappears in ''[[Sonic Forces]]'', having partially turned to desert due to resource depletion by Eggman's industries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hY3KVTMm264|title=Sonic Forces - Classic Sonic Green Hill Gameplay|author=Sonic the Hedgehog|date=April 25, 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref>
In addition, Green Hill appears as a stage in the [[2.5D]] [[fighting game]] ''[[Sonic Battle]]'',<ref>{{cite video game|title=[[Sonic Battle]]|date=January 5, 2004|publisher=[[THQ]]|developer=Sonic Team|level=Stage select screen|quote='''Description:''' MAP: GREEN HILL}}</ref> in the [[tennis]] video game ''[[Sega Superstars Tennis]]'', in the sports video game ''[[Mario & Sonic at the Sochi 2014 Olympic Winter Games]]'', in the mobile title ''[[Sonic Dash]]'', in the crossover adventure game ''[[Lego Dimensions]]'', and in the crossover fighting games ''[[Super Smash Bros. Brawl]]'', ''[[Super Smash Bros. for Nintendo 3DS]]'', ''[[Super Smash Bros. Ultimate]]'', and ''[[Dengeki Bunko: Fighting Climax]]''.<ref>{{cite video game|title=[[Super Smash Bros. Brawl]]|developer=[[Sora, Ltd.]]|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=March 9, 2008|quote='''Description:''' SONIC THE HEDGEHOG: GREEN HILL ZONE|level=Stage select screen}}</ref><ref>{{cite video game|title=[[Super Smash Bros. for Nintendo 3DS]]|developer=[[Bandai Namco Games Inc.]]|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=October 3, 2014|quote='''Description:''' SONIC THE HEDGEHOG: GREEN HILL ZONE|level=Stage select screen}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical reception=== Green Hill Zone has received consistently positive opinions from critics, particularly for its music. Craig Snyder at ''MakeUseOf'' named the level as one of the five best levels in video games, calling it "a great way to prepare for what’s to come".<ref>{{cite web|last=Snyder|first=Craig|url=http://www.makeuseof.com/tag/5-of-the-best-video-game-areas-levels-and-dungeons/ |title=5 Of The Best Video Game Areas, Levels, And Dungeons |publisher=[[MakeUseOf]]|date=October 31, 2013|accessdate=May 4, 2014}}</ref> <!-- Shaun Munro of WhatCulture listed it as the second best level in video games, describing it as "such an immaculate level design that it’s something developers still aspire to nowadays, though resolutely fail to live up to". He also praises the level's soundtrack and frenetic pace.<ref>{{cite web|last=Munro|first=Shaun|url=http://whatculture.com/gaming/10-best-video-game-levels-of-all-time.php/9 |title=10 Best Video Game Levels Of All Time » Page 9 of 10 |publisher=WhatCulture|date= |accessdate=May 4, 2014}}</ref> --> ''[[Game Informer]]''{{'}}s Tim Turi found the level's music "catchy",<ref name="catchy"/> and Wong ranked it as the thirteenth greatest piece of gaming music from the [[fourth generation of video game consoles|16-bit era]].<ref name="complex"/> In 2010, [[Sega]]'s community manager, Aaron Webber, returned from a vacation to find his cubicle redecorated to resemble Green Hill; [[IGN]]'s Levi Buchanan claimed that "everyone wants to come back to" this,<ref name="cubicle">{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2010/08/12/who-wants-to-work-in-the-green-hill-zone|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=August 12, 2010|last=Buchanan|first=Levi|accessdate=May 3, 2014|title=Who Wants to Work in the Green Hill Zone?}}</ref> and Owen Good of [[Kotaku]] exclaimed "I want to work in Green Hill Zone, too!"<ref name="want">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5611732/prank-redecorates-sega-desk-as-green-hill-zone|publisher=[[Kotaku]]|title=Prank Redecorates Sega Desk As Green Hill Zone|date=August 12, 2010|last=Good|first=Owen|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> Writing for the ''[[Sabotage Times]]'', Carl Anka ranked the original ''Sonic the Hedgehog'' as having the greatest music of any video game, largely as a result of Green Hill's theme.<ref name="anka"/>
Critics have compared levels, particularly first levels, of later ''Sonic'' games to Green Hill. Turi considers Emerald Hill from ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog 2]]'', Mushroom Hill from ''[[Sonic & Knuckles]]'', and Seaside Hill from ''[[Sonic Heroes]]'' to fit the same general mold as Green Hill, noting repetition in ''Sonic'' level design and stating that "gamers have played Green Hill Zone dozens of times." However, he has opined that the ''Sonic Generations'' version of the original Green Hill "trounces them all" in both its 2D and 3D incarnations.<ref name="catchy">{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/sonic_generations/b/xbox360/archive/2011/04/18/bridging-a-20-year-generation-gap-with-two-gameplay-styles.aspx|publisher=''[[Game Informer]]''|title=Sonic Generations: Bridging A 20-Year Generation Gap With Two Gameplay Styles|date=April 18, 2011|last=Turi|first=Tim|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> Justin Baker of [[Nintendo World Report]] and Skrebels both analogized Windy Hill from ''[[Sonic Lost World]]'' to Green Hill,<ref name="trailer">{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/news/34359/first-trailer-for-sonic-lost-world-released|publisher=[[Nintendo World Report]]|date=May 28, 2013|last=Baker|first=Justin|title=First Trailer for Sonic Lost World Released|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name="onm">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/54258/previews/sonic-lost-world-preview/|publisher=''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]''|date=September 8, 2013|last=Skrebels|first=Joe|title=Sonic Lost World preview|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> while Carter thought similarly of ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' [[downloadable content]] levels.<ref name="yoshi"/> The decision to include Green Hill in other titles in the series, such as ''[[Sonic Forces]]'', has been a source of debate among some fans, who believe that Sega has overused the stage since its debut.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Frank|first1=Allegra|title=Sonic fans are getting a little tired of Green Hill Zone|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/4/26/15435090/sonic-forces-green-hill-zone-gameplay|website=Polygon|accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref>
===Impact and legacy=== [[File:Green Hill Generations.png|thumb|Green Hill as it appears in 3D ("Modern") form in ''[[Sonic Generations]]'']] Green Hill Zone has also been recognized by critics as a classic, well-known video game level. It has been described as "classic" by Samit Sarkar of [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] and by Jim Sterling and Chris Carter of [[Destructoid]].<ref name="yoshi">{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/impressions-sonic-lost-world-yoshi-s-island-zone-267689.phtml|publisher=Destructoid|title=A very brief, but welcome joyride|last=Carter|first=Chris|date=December 18, 2013|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name="polygon">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/7/4407494/sonic-lost-world-gameplay-footage|publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|title=Sonic: Lost World gameplay footage shows off three very different levels|last=Sarkar|first=Samit|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name="fourpointfive">{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/e3-sonic-generations-might-get-more-than-a-4-5-203416.phtml|title=E3: Sonic Generations might get more than a 4.5|last=Sterling|first=Jim|publisher=Destructoid|date=June 9, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> Comparably, Joe Skrebels of ''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]'' called it "nostalgic",<ref name="onm"/> while Christopher Grant from [[Joystiq]] considered it to have a place "in the center of your retro-gaming shrine".<ref name="paper"/> Kevin Wong of ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' stated that the game's and level's popularity were such that "even if you didn't have a Genesis, this was the level you played at the department store while your parents went shopping."<ref name="complex">{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/video-games/2013/09/best-video-game-music/sonic-the-hedgehog|publisher=''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]''|date=September 5, 2013|last=Wong|first=Kevin|title=The Best Video Game Music of the 16-Bit Era|accessdate=May 14, 2014}}</ref> Andy Kelly from ''[[Computer and Video Games]]'' called the Green Hill theme a "monumental slice of Sega nostalgia",<ref name="cvg">{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/345195/features/video-game-soundtracks-the-100-best-themes-of-all-time-part-1/|publisher=''[[Computer and Video Games]]''|last=Kelly|first=Andy|title=Video game soundtracks: The 100 best themes of all time (Part 1)|date=April 28, 2012|accessdate=May 14, 2014}}</ref> and [[GamesRadar]] writer Justin Towell also referred to it as classic.<ref name="radar">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/hands-on-with-sonic-generations-on-3ds-reveals-1991-green-hill-act-1-layout-in-3d/|publisher=[[GamesRadar]]|last=Towell|first=Justin|title=Hands-on with Sonic Generations on 3DS reveals 1991 Green Hill Act 1 layout... in 3D|accessdate=May 15, 2014|date=July 20, 2011}}</ref> Anka has summarized that "Green Hill Zone in the original game has gone down as an instantly recognisable piece of music in pop culture".<ref name="anka">{{cite web|url=http://sabotagetimes.com/reportage/halo-4-10-other-great-original-videogame-soundtracks/|publisher=''[[Sabotage Times]]''|date=June 18, 2013|title=10 Of The Best Original Videogame Soundtracks|accessdate=May 15, 2014}}</ref>
To mark Sonic's fifteenth anniversary in 2006, Sega released a [[papercraft]] version of Green Hill as a [[PDF]] on its website.<ref name="paper">{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2006/06/26/build-sonic-a-papercraft-playground-for-his-bday/|publisher=[[Joystiq]]|date=June 26, 2006|last=Grant|first=Christopher|title=Build Sonic a papercraft playground for his Bday|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref> In 2011, not long after the release of ''Sonic Generations'', Sega held a contest inviting gamers to upload [[YouTube]] video playthroughs of the game's 3D version of Green Hill completed in less than one minute and fifty seconds; winners were eligible for ''Sonic'' merchandise.<ref name="onefifty">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5855903/run-green-hill-zone-in-under-150-and-collect-some-nice-sonic-merch|publisher=Kotaku|title=Run Green Hill Zone in Under 1:50 and Collect Some Nice ''Sonic'' Merch|last=Good|first=Owen|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2014}}</ref>

page.title: List of East Japan Railway Company stations

revision.text:
'''List of East Japan Railway Company stations''' lists [[East Japan Railway Company]] (JR East) stations, including lines serving the station and daily ridership. ==Summary== The reported ridership is the most recent figure available, and represents average daily entries at each station, excluding in-system transfers. For “interface” stations that allow for through-servicing and transfers with other railways without exiting the station's [[paid area]]—e.g., [[Ayase Station|Ayase]] on the [[Tokyo Metro Chiyoda Line|Chiyoda Line]]—the reported ridership includes cross-company passengers on through-servicing trains (as part of [[trackage rights]] agreements) or transferring from other railways' trains without passing through faregates. For stations served by both Shinkansen and non-Shinkansen services, the reported ridership includes Shinkansen station entries. ==Stations== ===Tokyo Suburban Area=== For its services in the [[Greater Tokyo Area]], JR East defines the {{nihongo|Tokyo Suburban Area|[http://www.jreast.co.jp/kippu/1103.html 東京近郊区間]}} for fare calculation purposes, roughly correlating with the [[Suica]] [http://www.jreast.co.jp/suica/area/tokyo/map.html coverage area] (as of 2012.03.17). However, Suica coverage does not extend to the [[Karasuyama Line]], [[Kashima Line]], and [[Kururi Line]], which are considered part of the Tokyo Suburban Area. As of 2012.03.17, there are a total of 624 “unique” passenger stations (i.e., counting stations served by multiple lines only once) in the Tokyo Suburban Area, excluding Shinkansen-only stations (e.g., [[Honjō-Waseda Station|Honjō-Waseda]]) {|class="wikitable sortable" ! style="text-align:left" | Station ! class=unsortable | JR East Lines ! class=unsortable | Other Lines !Code ! style="text-align:right" | Daily Station Entries ! style="text-align:right" | Source Year |- | [[Abiko Station (Chiba)|Abiko]] || {{color|#3333ff|■}} [[Jōban Line]]

{{Distinguish|List of Microsoft Windows components}} {{see also|Microsoft Mobile Services}}
[[Microsoft Corporation]] is a leading developer of [[Personal computer|PC]] software. It is best known for its [[Windows]] operating system, the [[Microsoft Office]] family of productivity software plus services, and the [[Visual Studio]] IDE. The company also publishes books (through [[Microsoft Press]]) and video games (through [[Microsoft Studios]]), and produces [[Microsoft hardware|its own line of hardware]]. The following is a list of the notable Microsoft software applications.

[[Image:Fukutoshin_Line_Shibuya_Station_002.JPG|300px|thumb|right|Color-coded wall paneling helps passengers inside the [[Tokyo Metro Fukutoshin Line]]’s [[Shibuya Station]] to navigate passages to connecting rail lines. [[Shibuya Station|Shibuya]] is the busiest station on the Tokyo Metro network and a major interchange with [[Tōkyū Corporation|Tōkyū]], [[Keiō Corporation|Keiō]], and [[East Japan Railway Company|JR East]] trains.]] '''List of Tokyo Metro stations''' lists stations on the [[Tokyo Metro]], including lines serving the station, station location ([[Special wards of Tokyo|ward]] or city), opening date, design (underground, at-grade, or elevated), and daily ridership. ==Summary== There are a total of 142 “unique” stations (i.e., counting stations served by multiple lines only once) on the Tokyo Metro network, or 179 total stations if each station on each line counts as one station.{{cite web|url=http://www.tokyometro.jp/corporate/enterprise/passenger_rail/transportation/passengers/index.html |title=各駅の乗降人員ランキング |publisher=東京地下鉄株式会社 |date= |accessdate=2012-06-04}} Tokyo Metro considers [[Kokkai-gijidō-mae Station|Kokkai-gijidō-mae]] and [[Tameike-Sannō Station|Tameike-Sannō]] as a single interchange station, despite the two stations having different names. If these are treated as separate stations, there are a total of 143 unique stations and 180 total stations. Most stations are located within the 23 special wards and fall inside the [[Yamanote Line]] loop—some wards such as [[Setagaya, Tokyo|Setagaya]] and [[Ōta, Tokyo|Ōta]] have no stations (or only a limited number of stations), as rail service in these areas has historically been provided by the [[Toei Subway]] or any of the various {{nihongo|major private railways|大手私鉄}}. In general, the reported daily ridership is the total of [[faregate]] entries and exits at each station, and excludes in-system transfers. However, Tokyo Metro reports ridership separately for stations directly shared with other railways—e.g., [[Shirokanedai Station|Shirokanedai]] and other [[Tokyo Metro Namboku Line|Namboku Line]] stations shared with the [[Toei Mita Line]]—or “interface” stations that allow for through-servicing and transfers with other railways without exiting the station's [[paid area]]—e.g., [[Ayase Station|Ayase]] on the [[Tokyo Metro Chiyoda Line|Chiyoda Line]]. For stations directly shared with other railways, the daily ridership only considers people using Tokyo Metro trains (or through-servicing trains owned by other railways operating as Tokyo Metro trains). For interface stations, the daily ridership also includes cross-company passengers on through-servicing trains (as part of [[trackage rights]] agreements) or transferring from other railways' trains without passing through faregates. Because of Tokyo Metro's reporting method, stations served by multiple lines that qualify both as shared or interface stations and as “regular” (i.e., not shared and non-interface) stations generally have their ridership separated out by station type. Examples include [[Shibuya Station|Shibuya]], where ridership for the interconnected [[Tokyo Metro Hanzōmon Line|Hanzōmon Line]] and [[Tokyo Metro Fukutoshin Line|Fukutoshin Line]] stations (which are interface stations for the [[Tōkyū Den-en-toshi Line]] and [[Tōkyū Tōyoko Line]], respectively) is separated out from ridership at the Shibuya [[terminal station]] of the [[Tokyo Metro Ginza Line|Ginza Line]], which does not have through-service arrangements with any other railways. Opening dates are given in standard Japanese date format (YYYY.MM.DD), and arranged from oldest to newest for stations served by multiple lines. ==Stations== ===Subway and commuter rail stations=== [[Image:Wakoshi Station platform 3-4 20121010.JPG|300px|thumb|right|Interface stations like [[Wakōshi Station]] are designed to facilitate through-service between Tokyo Metro and other railways, in this case between the [[Tōbu Tōjō Line]] and the [[Tokyo Metro Yūrakuchō Line|Tokyo Metro Yūrakuchō]] and [[Tokyo Metro Fukutoshin Line|Fukutoshin Lines]]. In addition to passengers passing through faregates to or from Tokyo Metro trains, ridership reported for these stations also includes passengers entering or exiting the Tokyo Metro system inside through-servicing trains, as well as passengers making cross-platform transfers between Tokyo Metro trains and other railways’ trains.]] {|class="wikitable sortable" ! style=text-align:left width=150 | Station ! class=unsortable width=50 | Lines ! width=100 | Ward or City ! width=100 | Opening date ! width=100 | Design ! width=100 | Daily ridership
